title: Questions re cryptic error message (like 'Error: ...some..hash') and spack.lock
body:
I have started building the next release of the software lib for our cluster using Spack, making much use of environments to specify package versions/variants, etc.  (I use environments to allow different settings for different compilers, etc).

Every one in a while, something happens and spack commands within a specific environment all start returning a cryptic error message.  Something like
Error: 'ghqdq26iqo52apxr2slpyqjirhpju42w'
I get this error from most any command, e.g. spack --env gcc840 find, on the environment in question (commands pointing to other environments seem to work OK).
I.e., no error message except for what appears to be a hash.  
The "hash" value is constant through the incident, and does not match the (normal) hashes for any installed packages (e.g. the hashes from spack find -L).

I am not sure what triggers the issue --- it seems to happen more frequently after something is uninstalled, but not always, and perhaps is related to changing package settings in the environments spack.yaml.

In the past, I discovered I could fix the "issue" by deleting and recreating/repopulating the environment, but that seems extreme.

I recently noticed that the hash corresponds to something in the environments spack.lock file.  Moreover, that if I delete the spack.lock file and then issue a "spack --env gcc840 concretize" command, it appears to fix the problem.

1) Is it safe to delete the spack.lock file for an environment?
2) Is there a better solution to this problem?
3) What does this error mean?  Can the error message be improved?
